"""
One writer on IMDB made the comment that the best movies "touch the soul." Shawshank 
RedempƟon achieves greatness, indeed perfecƟon, not because of special eﬀects or acƟon or 
violence or any semblance of distracƟon. It achieves greatness because it touches the soul with a 
straighƞorward cinemaƟc experience ﬁlled with brilliant dialogue, exemplary performances and a 
message of hope in the midst of the darkest of Ɵmes. It is a message that resonates deeply and grows 
more intense with each subsequent viewing of the ﬁlm. 
 
The ﬁrst Ɵme I viewed Shawshank RedempƟon I didn't ﬁnd it to be anything special. Sure, stars Tim 
Robbins and Morgan Freeman were good BUT their performances weren't anything special...or so I 
thought at the Ɵme. 
 
Frank Darabont directs Shawshank RedempƟon with a gentle, guiding hand allowing the actors to 
discover the essence within their characters. Some actors, undoubtedly, would not be up to the task. 
Robbins and Freeman, however, are not "some actors." They are consummate actors and masterful in 
their portrayals here. 
 
Based upon Stephen King's novella, Darabont creates a ﬁlm that never buys into the drama of its 
story, instead choosing to present the lives of the characters involved without histrionics. I have long 
felt, in fact, that the ﬁlm may even improve upon the novella by bringing it into focus and providing it 
with a pacing that allows a more explicit character development. 
 
I have noƟced that many of my favorite ﬁlms are ensemble pieces, and while Robbins and Freeman 
shine here it is actually the enƟre cast that brings this story to life with such grace and beauty. 
SupporƟng performances by the likes of James Whitmore, William Sadler, Gil Bellows and others who 
take what could be caricatures and give them in-depth personaliƟes and thoughts and feelings. 
 
Thomas Newman's score is supremely divine and changes along with the characters. It further 
enhances Darabont's pacing, as well. There are so many memorable scenes in Shawshank 
RedempƟon, however, the closing scene is certainly among one of the best closing scenes ever 
witnessed. 
 
It is hard to fathom that a "prison" movie could be a source of tremendous hope, light and 
inspiraƟon. Yet, to call Shawshank RedempƟon a prison movie is to minimize its greatness. It is a 
brilliant ﬁlm, a study of humanity in all its wonder AND it happens to take place within the conﬁnes of 
a prison. 
 
Moving, brilliant, inspiraƟonal, hopeful and empowering are all words that describe "The Shawshank 
RedempƟon." With outstanding performances from its ensemble cast and a work of tremendous 
cinemaƟc poetry by director Frank Darabont. "Shawshank RedempƟon" creates a stellar vision that 
teaches, challenges, inspires and evokes a wide array of emoƟons and thoughts that serves to remind 
us that in the darkest moments of our lives there is always a light that shines within.
